sofya.ed.semantic
Interface EventListener

All Known Subinterfaces:
ChainedEventListener
All Known Implementing Classes:
AutomataController, ConsoleTarget, DefaultEventClassifier, DynamicEscapeDetector, EventClassifier, EventFilter, EventSelectionFilter, HappenBeforeChecker, MultiLocksetRaceDetector, ObjectBasedRouter, ObjectBasedSplitter, ObjectEventFilter, RBAutomata, RBAutomataExt52, ThreadBasedSplitter, TraceFileTarget
public interface EventListener

Defines event notifications corresponding to observable events occurring in a module being traced.

This interface serves a dual-purpose of hiding dependence on the com.sun.jdi packages, since Sun guidelines state that such packages are not part of the official JDK. Clients of the event dispatcher framework are therefore shielded from having to deal with any changes to the interfaces in those packages. The one notable exception is the handling of mirrored values, for which constructing facades has been decided to add little value and considerable overhead.

Version:
08/02/2007
Author:
Alex Kinneer

Field Detail

objectRefs

static final gnu.trove.TLongObjectHashMap objectRefs
Stores strong references to any ObjectReference objects that have been requested by clients of the framework (except where otherwise noted in method contracts).

The JDI does not guarantee that two ObjectReference objects will return the same unique ID for the same remote object if the first ObjectReference has been garbage collected. This is a shortcoming of the JDI, and is a problem for clients that need to be able to track object identity through multiple events (which yield distinct ObjectReference objects). This cache protects the references from garbage collection, ensuring consistent object ID's. The references are keyed on the unique ID returned for the reference at the time of storage. This allows clients to release objects from protection at their discretion.

If clients wish to remove objects from the cache to free memory, they should be aware that the cache is visible to all implementors of the interface. Thus it is the responsiblity of all listener classes to define their own protocol for managing the release of references! It is possible for careless clients to alter the cache in ways that are destructive to other clients.

executionStarted

void executionStarted()
Notification that the system has begun executing user code.

This event will be preceded by thread start events.

newAllocationEvent

void newAllocationEvent(EventListener.ThreadData td,
                        EventListener.NewAllocationData nad)
Notification that an object was allocated by a NEW instruction.

This event cannot yet associate a unique identifier with the object, because this event only represents the allocation of a reference to which an object of a given class may be assigned. In other words, no actual object has yet been created. A unique ID can be obtained once a constructor is executed, which is signaled by the constructorEnterEvent(sofya.ed.semantic.EventListener.ThreadData, sofya.ed.semantic.EventListener.ObjectData, sofya.ed.semantic.EventListener.MethodData).

Parameters:
td - Information about the thread which allocated the object.
nad - Information about the new allocation.

constructorCallEvent

void constructorCallEvent(EventListener.ThreadData td,
                          EventListener.CallData cd)
Notification that a constructor was invoked.

Parameters:
td - Information about the thread which invoked the constructor.
cd - Information about the particular constructor which was invoked.

constructorEnterEvent

void constructorEnterEvent(EventListener.ThreadData td,
                           EventListener.ObjectData od,
                           EventListener.MethodData md)
Notification that a constructor was entered.

This is the first point during the object creation process at which the object can be uniquely identified.

Parameters:
td - Information about the thread executing the constructor.
od - Information about the object under construction. At the time of this event, only the object ID will be valid.
md - Information about the entered constructor.

constructorExitEvent

void constructorExitEvent(EventListener.ThreadData td,
                          EventListener.ObjectData od,
                          EventListener.MethodData md,
                          boolean exceptional)
Notification that a constructor was exited.

NOTE: This event is raised only if the constructor completes normally. If a constructor throws an escaping exception, the object is not successfully created and thus further events related to the object are not possible.

Parameters:
td - Information about the thread executing the constructor.
od - Information about the object under construction. At the time of this event, only the object ID will be valid.
md - Information about the exited constructor.
exceptional - Flag indicating whether the method exited by throwing an exception.

td - Information about the thread in which the field access occurred.
fd - Information about the accessed field.
